resources.string: Farmbot
Cool-Season Crops (e.g., lettuce, spinach, peas, broccoli):
• Germination: 40°F to 75°F (4°C to 24°C) \n• Optimum Growth: 55°F to 75°F (13°C to 24°C)\n• Flowering: 55°F to 75°F (13°C to 24°C)
Warm-Season Crops (e.g., tomatoes, corn, peppers, cucumbers):

• Germination: 60°F to 95°F (15°C to 35°C)
• Optimum Growth: 70°F to 85°F (21°C to 29°C)
• Flowering: 70°F to 85°F (21°C to 29°C)
• Fruit Development: 75°F to 95°F (24°C to 35°C)
Tropical Crops (e.g., bananas, mangoes, pineapples):
• Germination: 70°F to 95°F (21°C to 35°C)\n• Optimum Growth: 75°F to 95°F (24°C to 35°C)
Root Crops (e.g., potatoes, carrots, radishes):
• Germination: 45°F to 85°F (7°C to 29°C) \n• Optimum Growth: 60°F to 80°F (15°C to 27°C)
Cereal Crops (e.g., wheat, rice, oats, barley):
• Germination: 40°F to 85°F (4°C to 29°C)\n• Optimum Growth: 65°F to 75°F (18°C to 24°C)
Fruit Trees (e.g., apple, citrus, peach):
• Optimum Growth (During Active Growth Period): 65°F to 85°F (18°C to 29°C)\n• Rest Period (Dormancy): Chilling requirement varies widely depending on the species and variety.
Grapes:
• Budbreak (Spring): 50°F to 70°F (10°C to 21°C)\n• Flowering: 60°F to 80°F (15°C to 27°C)\n• Fruit Set: 70°F to 90°F (21°C to 32°C)
Seed Germination:

• Optimal Humidity Range: 70% to 90% \n• Suggestion: Higher humidity helps to retain moisture around seeds, promoting germination. You can use a humidity dome or cover to maintain high humidity levels during germination.
Vegetative Growth:

• Optimal Humidity Range: 50% to 70% \n• Suggestion: During the vegetative growth stage, moderate humidity levels are suitable for most plants. This range helps plants maintain water uptake while minimizing the risk of fungal diseases.
Flowering and Fruiting:
• Optimal Humidity Range: 40% to 60% \n• Suggestion: Lower humidity during flowering and fruiting stages helps prevent issues like powdery mildew and improves pollination efficiency.
Tropical Plants:
• Optimal Humidity Range: 60% to 80% \n• Suggestion: Tropical plants generally thrive in higher humidity environments. Use misting or a humidifier to maintain appropriate humidity levels.
Desert Plants:
• Optimal Humidity Range: 30% to 50% \n• Suggestion: Desert plants are adapted to low humidity conditions, so avoid excessive humidity to prevent issues like rot.
Greenhouses:

• Optimal Humidity Range: Varies based on the crop, but generally between 40% to 70% \n• Suggestion: Greenhouse humidity levels need to be carefully managed. Proper ventilation and use of humidifiers or misting systems can help maintain optimal conditions.
Indoor Houseplants:

• Optimal Humidity Range: Varies based on plant type, but generally between 40% to 60% \n• Suggestion: Indoor environments can have lower humidity levels due to heating or air conditioning. Use humidifiers or place plants on trays with pebbles and water to increase humidity around them.
Dry Soil:

• Moisture Range: 0 to 20% \n• Suggestion: When the soil moisture is in the lower range (0 to 20%), the soil is considered dry. In this condition, plants may experience water stress, and irrigation is necessary to maintain healthy growth. Water the plants to increase the moisture level in the soil.
Moist Soil:
Optimal Soil Moisture:

• Moisture Range: 40% to 60% \n• Suggestion: This range is often considered the optimal moisture level for most crops. It provides sufficient water for plants to grow and access nutrients efficiently. Try to maintain the soil moisture within this range for the best results.
Slightly Wet Soil:

• Moisture Range: 60% to 80% \n• Suggestion: In this range, the soil is slightly wet. While some crops may tolerate slightly wet conditions, prolonged exposure to excessive moisture may lead to root rot and other issues. Ensure proper drainage to prevent waterlogged soil.
Waterlogged Soil:

• Moisture Range: 80% to 100% \n• Suggestion: Waterlogged soil occurs when the moisture level is too high, and the soil cannot drain properly. This can suffocate plant roots and lead to plant stress. Improve drainage to avoid waterlogging.
Overwatering Alert:

• Moisture Range: Above 100% (saturated soil) \n• Suggestion: If the moisture reading exceeds 100%, it indicates saturated soil, which is a clear sign of overwatering. Overwatering can lead to oxygen deprivation in the soil and root rot. Adjust the irrigation schedule to prevent overwatering.

• Moisture Range: 20% to 40% \n• Suggestion: In this range, the soil is considered moist, and plants are adequately hydrated. This is generally the ideal range for most crops during active growth. Monitor the soil to ensure it stays within this range for optimal plant development.
Acidic Soil:

• pH range: (below 6.0) 
• Plants that Thrive: Acid-loving plants like blueberries, azaleas, rhododendrons, and some conifers. 
• Nutrient Availability: Some nutrients like iron, manganese, and aluminum become more available, but phosphorus and calcium may become less available. 
• Management: If growing acid-loving plants, maintain pH within their preferred range. For other crops, consider adding lime to raise pH if it's too low.
Slightly Acidic to Neutral Soil:
Slightly Alkaline Soil:

• pH range: (7.0 – 7.5) 
• Plants that Thrive: Some legumes, beets, broccoli, and many other common crops. 
• Nutrient Availability: Phosphorus, calcium, and magnesium are more available in this range. 
• Management: Many crops do well in this range, but be cautious if the pH is increasing over time, as it might lead to alkalinity issues.

• pH range: (6.0 – 7.0) 
 • Plants that Thrive: Many vegetables, fruits, ornamentals, and common crops prefer this range. 
• Nutrient Availability: Most essential nutrients are optimally available to plants in this range. 
• Microbial Activity: Beneficial microbial activity is usually highest in this range. 
• Management: Maintain pH in this range for a wide range of crops. Regular soil testing can help adjust pH if needed.
Moderately Alkaline Soil

• pH range: (7.5 – 8.5) 
• Plants that Thrive: Certain grasses, asparagus, and other plants that tolerate alkaline conditions. 
• Nutrient Availability: Availability of some micronutrients might decrease. 
• Management: Some crops can tolerate this range, but it's important to monitor nutrient availability and address potential deficiencies.
Highly Alkaline Soil

• pH range: (above 8.5) 
• Plants that Thrive: Few crops thrive in highly alkaline soils, but some desert plants can adapt. 
• Nutrient Availability: Many nutrients become less available, leading to deficiencies. 
• Management: Amend soil to lower pH if growing crops not adapted to highly alkaline conditions. Choose tolerant plants or consider container gardening.
